SEARCH
Package koopa.core.data

Class Token

java.lang.Object
koopa.core.data.Token
All Implemented Interfaces:
Data
public class Token extends Object implements Data
This is the main data item generated by Koopa. They represent pieces of text, and can carry some metadata in the form of tags.

Tags themselves can be anything; though we recommend using enums.

Trying to keep this class immutable.

  • Field Details

    • text

      private final String text

    • ranges

      private final List<Range> ranges
      Which Ranges make up this token ?

      Unmodifiable, and always based on a copy of any provided list of ranges !

    • tags

      private final Set<Object> tags
      Which tags does this token carry ?

      Unmodifiable !

    • replaced

      private final Replaced replaced

    • skipped

      private boolean skipped
      Was this token skipped during the parse, or not ?

      This is a mutable field in an immutable class. Which, of course, is not what you want. But I made this field mutable for performance reasons. The preferred way was to add this info as another tag, but this was one piece of information which was added and retracted so often that it imposed too much of a performance penalty on the runtime (adding about 30% of time to parsing the testsuite).

      Alternate solutions considered:

      • Markers, such as for water. But there would be way too many of these as well.
      • Asking the grammar. But that only tells you whether a token can be skipped, not whether it actually was in the end. Removing the ambiguity is not an option for Cobol.
      • Counting schemes, or separate bookkeeping, in HoldingTarget. Felt too complex and cumbersome.

    • hashCounter

      private static int hashCounter

    • HASHCODE

      private final int HASHCODE

  • Constructor Details

    • Token

      public Token(String text, Position start, Position end, Object... tags)
      Creates a new token from the given text, boundaries and tags.

      Start and end positions should belong to the same resource. I.e. start.getResourceName() and (end.getResourceName()) are both null, or are equal.

    • Token

      Token(String text, List<Range> ranges, Set<Object> tags, Replaced replacing)
      NOTE This is package scoped on purpose. Intended for use by Tokens only.

    • Token

      Token(List<Token> tokens, Object... tags)
      Creates a new token which is equivalent to the composition of the given ones, except for their tags.

      The tags of the original tokens are not aggregated. Instead you can specify whatever tags the new token should have as extra parameters.

      The Ranges of the original tokens, however, do get aggregated into the new one.

      The new token will not be seen as replacing some other token, despite what any of the given tokens may say.

      NOTE This is package scoped on purpose. Please use the Tokens.join(List, Object...) method instead.

    • Token

      private Token(Token token, Replaced replacing)
      Create a copy of one token, and register the copy as being a replacement for another one.

    • withTags

      public Token withTags(Object... additionalTags)
      Creates a new token which is a copy of this one, with the addition of the given tags. If there are no tags given, or they are all already there, returns this instead.

    • withoutTags

      public Token withoutTags(Object... theseTags)
      Creates a new token which is a copy of this one, with the exception of the given tags. If there are no tags given, or none of them are found here, returns this instead.

    • replacingTag

      public Token replacingTag(Object oldTag, Object newTag)
      Creates a new token which is a copy of this one, minus one tag (if present), and with the addition of the other.

      Creates a copy of this token, while linking it to another one by saying that this token replaces it, either completely or in part.
